It is sad to see the suffering, it is good to see the volunteer. However, it is incomprehensible that the Secretary of DHHS has not requested funding for the US Surgeon General to activate the US Public Health Service Ready Reserve Corps - established in 1917 - to provide federal health care reservists to assist in these terrible disasters. Hundreds of these reservists have served during past national emergencies; and many would be of great assistance to the patients and families of St John's Hospital; or to operate emergency medical stations in the area. Local medical volunteers are great, but the Federal Government must be prepared to deploy US Public Health Service reservists where needed-when needed, if not now, when?

There are so many issues here one hardly knows where to begin. When private prisons place profiteering over human rights, overcrowding is an inevitable result. The more men each prison can cram into any available space, the more money received in terms of state funding. The shareholders are happy, the public is happy, deluded in the belief that overcrowded prisons symbolize safety in the streets. Sadly, many of these men should not be in prison. Don't get me wrong. I am way, way far away from being a bleeding heart when it comes to criminals and criminal behavior. However, California's 'three strikes' law proved to be an abysmal failure years ago. How many people are in prison now for stealing packages of bologna or six packs of beer? What about the famous case about ten years ago where a man hit a third strike stealing a golf club from a sporting goods store? The theft of that club cost him his freedom, for life. Is that a wise expenditure of taxpayer money? Do you feel safer, California, in your gated communities, knowing that a golf club thief is no longer on the loose?

The most abject disgrace and a large cause of prison over-crowding is a lack of mental health facilities for the poor and indigent. Instead of receiving proper medical attention, men with schizophrenia, bipolar disorder and other disabling mental illnesses are thrown into frightening, subhuman conditions. As Americans, we once decried a society that would house people in a place called Bedlam. Lest we forget, Bedlam was at first founded on progressive, altruistic principles. Today we've a modern Bedlam and it's called the for-profit prison industry. It keeps everyone happy: the politicians continue getting re-elected for appearing tough on crime, the populace feels safer because pot smoking, golf club stealing, mentally ill indigents are off the streets and out of sight, the for-profit prisons are rolling in dough and their shareholders greedily count their dividends.

Let's stop the charade that stuffing people into prisons will keep us safer. We live in one of the most violent societies in the developed world, proof enough that no matter how manner people we lock away, we'll always find more who pose a threat. It's time to spend money wisely and morally. It's time to get these sick men the help they need, the medication and the aftercare they need so they can lead productive lives, according to their god given human rights. Profits of people? Let's stop the insanity
Yes, but what does Paul Krugman say about it?

David Cameron did not get elected promising to tear down their single payer health care system. Nor did Labor announce that their first priority would be to do whatever possible to defeat the Cameron government the day after the election. Politics in the US, in contrast, has all the earmarks of bad private capitalism which tends to view the competition as an enemy and aims to maximize short-term gains (read, those over 55 are exempt from any medicare revision pains).

The checks and balances inherent in the US constitutional system is definitely a factor in the current state of affairs, further exacerbated by the super majority rule in the Senate. The solution, in my judgment, does not lie in coming up with compromise solutions. Rather, we should allow time for solutions - any solution - to work. If Cameron's policies don't work, the English electorate and the opposition parties will work to change the policies but only after giving it a chance. We should do something similar here. A good first step would be to get rid of the 60 vote super majority rule in the Senate.

This is like saying that we will evaluate the efficiency of the fire department by counting the number of arrests made by the police. If students are forced to take tests that judge the teachers, but not themselves, why would the students try to do well on the test?

This very idea exposes the true goal of Mayor Bloomberg and the rest of the entrepreneurs who are seeking to privatize the school system. They don't even care how the students actually preform, or what the students actually know. They are just concerned with building evidence to allow them to lay off experienced teachers.

Why doesn't someone develop a test for teachers to take that would evaluate them. We don't evaluate doctors on whether on not their patients remember to take their medicine, or construction workers based on whether home owners choose to paint their kitchen white or red. Why are teachers the only profession that is evaluated based on how someone else performs on a test?

I think there' too much wishful thinking here, but, for once, it's not too material. Contrary to what you might like to see, there's not much chance that the Libyan operation will escalate enough to deliver a quick resolution: the Europeans can't afford it and Obama won't spend political capital on it. Nonetheless, I don;t think Gadafi can survive an extended campaign. His revenues will fall aa that of the insurgents increases. His forces will degrade as organization and training among the rebels improves. The result will not be stalemate but attrition, and Gadafi can't win that game.

In the larger sense, though, an independent European foreign policy won't mean much if Europe insists on cutting its armed forces. Not every problem will invivle a fifth-rater like Gadafi.

I'd be very wary as a client to have an attorney who could be hired by the firm at a not-very-competitive salary, and who is then demotivated by the dead-endedness of his position.

This is not an area where I'd want to save money at the cost of excellence.

I have a suggestion. Why don't the firms pay off the student debt of any lawyer accepting the second tier. Perhaps they could spread it over a period of years. Do the math. $160000 a year for the hot shot that can pay off his or her debt versus $60,000 for the lawyer who wants to spend time with his family, work in the yard, have a hobby etc. So we pay the debt off for this lawyer at say $40000 a year until its gone. Besides you can have a pretty good time in Wheeling and Dayton. I have spent a lot of time in both cities. The tortise sees more of the road than the hare.

Bravo, Mr. Brooks, you have determined that a horse is not the same as a fish. Well done.

The British system of government does not function under a written constitution. There isn't space here to enumerate the ways in which this makes British politics different from American politics.

In Britain, money is not so stifling in elections; this is partly because campaigns are shorter, taking weeks instead of years, and because in the UK general election candidates are guaranteed time on the TV and radio, and can take advantage of the national press, while in the US everything has to be bought. Plus, whatever money is needed is donated completely in the open; there is no Citizens United. Do you not think this is huge? Do you not think American politicians have to sell their souls to Big Money?

I could go on at length. Britons are really very different people from Americans. To make the kind of comparisons you make in a brief article is misleading to the point of utter dishonesty. This kind of writing has no place in a newspaper like the NYT. You not only fail to shed light, you shed darkness.

It's time for D. Brooks to lose the phrase "welfare state" and think a little about what a complex society should be. First, societies advance by allowing individuals to specialize and concentrate on what they do best and count on their fellow citizens to do likewise. I believe that's Economics 1. Second, in such a rational society (not a welfare state), someone is taking care of the basic needs to allow individuals to specialize.

For the citizens who are damaged one way or another, such a rational society provides for their basic needs, rather than allowing them to die in public or private.

Such a rational society is structured to encourage individuals to develop themselves to the fullest, by providing education in all its aspects, without requiring them first to have (or borrow) enough money before they can take their place as productive citizens of the rational society. Then, the rational society would consider gainful and productive employment to be an individual's right and the society's need.

Who is more "invested" in a publicly held corporation, the "investor" whose holdings in such a corporation is a recommended three percent of their portfolio, or the employee whose peace of mind and body depends on their job?

David, don't ever write "welfare society" again; it discredits your every argument.

Parliamentary democracy works incredibly well -- much better than the U.S. separation of powers. With a few minor tweaks, Mr. Brook's description of British political culture could be applied to Canadian political culture, as well. In both countries, strong parliamentary majorities are able to take decisive steps -- implementing necessary tax cuts or much-needed social programs -- because they don't have to worry about a never-ending election cycle or an obstructionist minority.

Canada, for example, faced a terrible debt problem in the late 1980s and early 1990s. In response, the Conservative government raised taxes and the Liberal government cut the federal budget. Can anyone in the U.S. imagine Democrats cutting public programs and Republicans boosting taxes? Never. And because no one can imagine that, no one should expect a sensible response to the current deficit and debt crisis.
